Award.AwardTitle: Integration and evolution of human and non-human primate postcranial morphology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The skeleton of the limbs and body plays an important role in locomotion, but the patterns of relationships among different aspect of bone shape (their integration) and the genes that affect these relationships remain poorly understood. This study develops a better understanding of how patterns of integration correspond to variation in primate movement and how genes affect the ways in which skeletal traits are integrated with one another. The research compares bone morphology among a large number of primate species to test the hypothesis that integration in the limbs is the result of adaptation by natural selection in response to the different performance requirements that species encounter. It uses a similar comparative approach to test hypotheses about whether patterns of integration structured or were structured by adaptive evolutionary shifts in response to selection on locomotor behavior. In order for bones to evolve, there must be genetic variation in bone shape and size, but there is little know about which genes are involved in producing this variation in normal, healthy organisms. This project uses a very large population of mice to relate aspects of bone shape and size to specific regions of the genome. Comparisons between the patterns of integration in mice and primates, including humans, will then help guide future investigations into what role these genes have had in the evolution and development of human skeletal morphology.
At a practical level, understanding how humans differ from our closest evolutionary relatives in skeletal patterns of integration will aid future studies of many physical health problems, such as back pain and bad knees, which are directly attributable to our unique morphology. Understanding the genetic basis of bone size and shape in the mouse will help guide future investigations into the development and hereditary basis of diseases that affect the skeleton. Understanding how the integration of bones varies across primates, including humans, will provide a fresh perspective on how these differences have evolved. This is particularly important when considering the origins of humans' unique, bipedal mode of locomotion. Additionally, the understanding of the genetics of bone shape will be very informative for continuing investigations into the links between development and the evolution of organismal form. This research will afford many students, including a substantial number from underrepresented groups, with hands-on research experience in a way that will help them be able to synthesize a new understanding of how organisms develop and evolve. Furthermore, students will receive training in state of the art morphometric scientific imaging, and statistical computing technologies and methods. This will allow them eventually to pursue fruitful independent research programs in any of several biomedical fields. Public understanding of science will be aided by the production of a large number of digital representations of bones that can help students at many educational levels visualize biological variation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Co-variation can constrain and enable evolutionary pathways. Moreover it can reflect functional and developmental influences and changes in patterns of co-variation might indicate important shifts in function and development. Primates are an ideal group in which to examine such covariation because they exhibit more locomotor and limb bone morphological diversity than any other Order of mammals.  Quantifying comparable morphologies in mouse models allows evaluation of the genetic underpinnings of these bone shapes. This research quantified levels of covariation among different aspects of morphology in the limbs and shoulder and pelvic girdles in a set of primates and an experimental mouse model to understand the genetic basis and evolution of these important structures. Our aims were threefold:


1: Achieve a better understanding of co-variation among aspects of limb and sholulder/pelvic girdles, associated with shifts in  function and development across multiple primate species.

2: Evaluate how natural selection and other evolutionary processes produced among-species differences.  

3: Use a mouse model to test hypotheses about how co-variation is built up and broken down by the effects of genes during development.


Outcomes:

We have tested hypotheses related to the evolution of primate limbs, pelves, and shoulders.  We find that primate species with greater limb length differentiation between fore- and hindlimbs (suspensory animals and humans) show greater evolutionary autonomy for these dimensions than do species with more similar length limbs.  We also find that the human pelvic dimensions are less constrained than those of other apes, especially for characteristics related to bipedal locomotion.  These results suggest that selection related to locomotor ability has acted on the skeletons of humans and other primates. Moreover, we find that the evolved differences in the pelvis and hip joint between humans and other apes were likely the product of complex patterns of natural selection rather than responses to selection on small numbers of traits.


We find that many regions of the genome influence variation in the shape and size of bones. A subset of these genomic regions influence more than one aspect of bone morphology and preliminary results suggest that the same genomic regions affect morphology in both the hip and shoulder. Genomic regions found to influence morphology appear to be enriched with genes hypothesized to interact with genes involved in developmental pathways underlying the growth and form of the skeleton.


Intellectual Merit:

A better understand the relationships between form, function, and co-variation affords us with an opportunity to distinguish between several competing hypotheses about adaptation and constraint in the evolution of primates. Co-variation among characteristics can constrain the kinds of evolutionary trajectories a species may take. Alternatively, co-variation may be highly labile and a direct byproduct of natural selection optimizing form and function. Teasing apart these possibilities opens up a new view on primate and human evolution.


Much of the work on primate evolution assumes that differences between species reflect adaptations to different environments. This assumption is seldom tested. Our work on covariation allows us to test hypotheses about whether a trait was under natural selection and which traits were most important for driving natural selection.
